Name: Portugal 10-year Government Bond Yield (with GFD Extension)
Periodicity:
Monthly From Jan 1806 To Sep 1988
Daily From Oct 1988 To Mar 2022
Metadata:
Sources: The Times, London, The Economist and Banker`s Magazine (1844-1930), League of Nations, Statistical Yearbook, Geneva: League of Nations (1931-45), Bank of Portugal, Quarterly Bulletin (1946-)
Notes: The Portugal 5% Bond (Amsterdam SE) (BGPRT5-AM) is used from August 1803 to December 1815, the Portugal 5% Loan of 1823 (BGPRT523-LO) is used from December 1823 to September 1833, the Portugal 5% Loan of 1833 (BGPRT533-LO) is used from October 1833 to December 1839, the Portugal 3% Irredeemable Loan of 1834 (BGPRT3-LO) is used from January 1840 to September 1842, the Portugal 5% Converted Loan of 1841 (BGPRT541-LO) is used from October 1842 to July 1856, the Portugal 3% Irredeemable Loan of 1834 is used from August 1856 to December 1869, the Portugal 3% Irredeemable Loan is used from January 1870 to November 1902, the Portuguese Unified 3% External Debt of 1902 - 1st Series (Redeemable 2001) is used from December 1902 to May 1954.
For domestic quotes, the yield to maturity of the 4 percent Centenary Loan of 1940 maturing in 1980 is used from July 1940 until 1980. After a military coup on April 24, 1975, the Lisbon and Porto stock exchanges were closed until December 1975. Bond yields are interpolated during those two years. An index of public debt bonds with a maturity of over 2 years is used from 1980 through August 1989. From September 1989 to June 1993, yields of public debt securities, subject to withholding tax which excludes investment and pension funds. Beginning in October 1988 daily data is provided for 10-year benchmark bonds.
Portugal defaulted on its debt in 1834, though the Brazilian government made payments on the Bonds of 1823 and 1833. In 1841, there was a general conversion of debt into 5% Bonds, which would pay 2.5% from July 1841 to 1845, 3% from July 1845 to 1849, 4% from July 1849 to 1853, and 5% from July 1853 until 1857 and 6% thereafter until the debt was paid off. In 1845, the stock was converted into a permanent 4% Stock. About 65% of bondholders accepted this scheme, and in 1850 and 1851, the government defaulted on bondholders who rejected the scheme. In 1852, however, the Portuguese government forced bondholders to convert to 3% bonds. Portugal subsequently issued all loans at 3%. In 1892, Portugal reduced the interest rate by 30% from 3% to 2.1% on internal loans and to 1% on external loans. In 1903, Portugal unified its debt with old 1853 bondholders receiving one-half new bond for each old bond, and began paying 3% interest once again, which it continued to do until those bonds were retired.
